- Changes in mood: Survey-based assessment (0-5 scale) of mood. Time frame: 30 days.
- Changes in brain fog: Survey-based assessment (0-5 scale) of brain fog experienced by participants. Time frame: 30 days.
- Change in body weight: Participants will weigh themselves at baseline and endline and provide their body weight. Time frame: 30 days.

# Introduction
The purpose of this document is to provide guidance on the selection of outcome measures for clinical trials of cancer immunotherapy. The document is intended to be used by investigators, sponsors, and other stakeholders involved in the design and conduct of clinical trials of cancer immunotherapy.

# Background
The use of immunotherapy in cancer treatment has been increasing over the past decade. Immunotherapy is a form of treatment that uses the body's immune system to fight cancer. It can be used alone or in combination with other treatments, such as chemotherapy or radiation therapy. Immunotherapy can be used to treat a variety of cancers, including melanoma, lung cancer, and kidney cancer.

Primary Outcome Measure:
1. Objective response rate (ORR) as assessed by blinded independent central review (BICR), using Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors version 1.1 (RECIST 1.1)
   - Measure Description: Proportion of patients with a best overall response of confirmed complete response (CR) or partial response (PR)
   - Time Frame: Up to 136 weeks

2. Overall survival (OS)
   - Measure Description: The time from randomization to the date of death due to any cause
   - Time Frame: Up to 5 years

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs)
   - Time Frame: Up to 136 weeks

2. Incidence of treatment-related TEAEs
   - Time Frame: Up to 136 weeks

3. Incidence of serious adverse events (SAEs)
   - Time Frame: Up to 136 weeks

4. Incidence of adverse events of special interest (AESIs)
   - Time Frame: Up to 136 weeks

5. Incidence of immune-mediated adverse events (imAEs)
   - Time Frame: Up to 136 weeks

6. Occurrence of interruption of study drug(s) due to TEAEs
   - Time Frame: Up to 136 weeks

7. Occurrence of discontinuation of study drug(s) due to TEAEs
   - Time Frame: Up to 136 weeks

    - Time Frame: Up to 136 weeks

    - Time Frame: Up to 136 weeks

Scores range from 0 (no neuropathy) to 4 (severe neuropathy), with a higher total score indicating a higher degree of peripheral neuropathy. What do you think about using this measure?

Your suggested time frame aligns well with the treatment period and allows us to monitor changes in the severity of peripheral neuropathy over time. It will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of the compress interventions in managing and reducing neuropathy symptoms. Now, let's move on to another aspect of peripheral neuropathy. We can assess the symptoms of peripheral neuropathy using the NCI-CTCAE scale, which includes evaluations of both motor and sensory nerves. The scale utilizes a grading system ranging from one (mild) to five (death) to characterize the extent of events. A higher grade indicates more severe symptoms. What do you think about using this measure?

Here's a summary of the outcome measures we discussed:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- The effectiveness of Cold and Hot Compress Nursing Interventions on the Quality of Life: Measure Description: Quality of Life will be assessed using the EORTC-QLQ-C30 scale, which evaluates symptoms, functionality, and overall health status/life quality. Higher scores indicate more severe symptoms, while higher scores in the functionality and overall health sections signify better conditions. Time Frame: (1) Before the initiation of the first chemotherapy session. (2) Before the 6th administration of chemotherapy drugs. (3) Before the 12th administration of chemotherapy drugs. (4) Within three months after the completion of the chemotherapy course.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- The effectiveness of Cold and Hot Compress Nursing Interventions on the Quality of Life and severity of Peripheral Neuropathy: Measure Description: Severity of Peripheral Neuropathy will be assessed using the EORTC QLQ-CIPN2 scale, which evaluates symptoms and functional limitations related to sensory, motor, and autonomic nervous system disorders. Higher scores indicate more severe symptoms. Time Frame: (1) Before the initiation of the first chemotherapy session. (2) Before each administration of chemotherapy drugs (total of 12 times). (3) Within three months after the completion of the chemotherapy course.

- The effectiveness of Cold and Hot Compress Nursing Interventions on the Severity of Peripheral Neuropathy: Measure Description: Severity of Peripheral Neuropathy will be assessed using the Total Neuropathy Score-clinical, which includes subjective symptoms and objective evaluations. Time Frame: (1) Before the initiation of Oxaliplatin treatment. (2) After the completion of the 6th injection until the start of the 7th injection (approximately three months into chemotherapy). (3) Within three months after the completion of the chemotherapy course.

# Introduction

## Background
The use of anesthesia in the elderly population is increasing. The number of elderly patients undergoing surgery is expected to increase by 50% by 2030. The elderly population is more sensitive to anesthesia than the younger population. The elderly population is more likely to experience postoperative complications, such as cognitive impairment, delirium, and postoperative mortality. Therefore, it is important to evaluate the safety and quality of anesthesia in the elderly population.

## Objectives
The objective of this study is to evaluate the safety and quality of anesthesia in the elderly population.

## Research questions

### Primary research question
What is the effect of Remimazolam besylate compared to Propofol on the safety and quality of anesthesia in the elderly population?

Excellent. Now, let's discuss the primary outcome measures for your study. Based on the information you've provided, there are several primary outcome measures. The first one is the AUC from timepoint 0 to infinity (AUCinf). This measure assesses the non-adjusted and baseline-adjusted PK parameters for nicotine, including the area under the curve from timepoint 0 to infinity. It will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Another primary outcome measure is the AUC from timepoint 0 to timepoint t (AUC0-t). This measure evaluates the non-adjusted and baseline-adjusted PK parameters for nicotine, including the area under the curve from timepoint 0 to a specific timepoint. Similar to the previous measure, it will be assessed at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Yes, there are a few more primary outcome measures we should consider. The AUC from timepoint 0 to 30 minutes (AUC0-30min) and AUC from timepoint 0 to 60 minutes (AUC0-60min) are important measures for assessing the early exposure and bioavailability of nicotine. They will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Both Cmax and Tmax are important primary outcome measures. Cmax assesses the maximum plasma concentration of nicotine achieved after IP use, while Tmax measures the time it takes to reach the maximum plasma concentration. These measures provide insights into the rate of absorption and the peak exposure of nicotine. They will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Certainly. The first secondary outcome measure is the in vivo extracted amount (mg/unit) of nicotine for each investigational product. This measure helps evaluate the efficiency of nicotine delivery and the consistency of nicotine content in the pouches. It will be assessed at visits 2 to 4.

Another secondary outcome measure is the in vivo extracted fraction (%) of nicotine for each investigational product. This measure provides information on the bioavailability and release characteristics of nicotine from the pouches. It will also be evaluated at visits 2 to 4.

Yes, there are a few more secondary outcome measures. We should assess the highest recorded increase (Emax) in pulse rate from baseline, which helps evaluate the acute physiological effects of nicotine on cardiovascular function. Additionally, we should measure the mean score for each palatability question 30 minutes after the start of IP use, which provides insights into taste, flavor, and overall user experience. We should also evaluate urge-to-use, product-liking, intent-to-use-again, and onset-of-effect after IP use to assess user satisfaction and behavioral responses. Finally, we should monitor the frequency, seriousness, and intensity of adverse events (AEs) to ensure participant safety throughout the study.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a new treatment for coccydynia. The treatment involves a combination of manual therapy and exercise. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial (RCT) design. The study will compare the effectiveness of the new treatment to a control group that receives only manual therapy. The study will also compare the effectiveness of the new treatment to a control group that receives only exercise. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial (RCT) design. # Methods

## Study design
The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial (RCT) design. The study will compare the effectiveness of the new treatment to a control group that receives only manual therapy. The study will also compare the effectiveness of the new treatment to a control group that receives only exercise.

## Participants
The study will include 100 participants who have been diagnosed with coccydynia. The participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: the new treatment group, the manual therapy group, or the exercise group. The participants in the new treatment group will receive a combination of manual therapy and exercise. The participants in the manual therapy group will receive only manual therapy. The participants in the exercise group will receive only exercise.

## Interventions
The participants in the new treatment group will receive a combination of manual therapy and exercise. The participants in the manual therapy group will receive only manual therapy. The participants in the exercise group will receive only exercise.

## Outcomes
The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the new treatment by comparing the outcomes of the new treatment group to the outcomes of the control groups. The outcomes will include pain levels, functional ability, and quality of life.

## Sample size
The study will include 100 participants. The sample size was determined based on a power analysis. The power analysis was conducted using G*Power software. The power analysis showed that a sample size of 100 participants would provide sufficient power to detect a difference between the new treatment group and the control groups.

# Overview
BBC1501 is a recombinant humanized monoclonal antibody that is being investigated for the treatment of neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD). BBC1501 is a humanized monoclonal antibody that binds to vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). VEGF is a protein that is involved in the formation of blood vessels. It is produced by the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and is involved in the development of new blood vessels.

### Change in CNV size according to fluorescein angiogram

The change in CNV size according to fluorescein angiogram will be measured by comparing the size of the CNV lesion at baseline and at the end of the study. The CNV lesion will be measured using the Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) grid. The ETDRS grid is a standardized method for measuring the size of the CNV lesion. It consists of a 1-mm grid with 9 subfields, each measuring 1 mm in diameter. The CNV lesion will be measured in each of the 9 subfields, and the total size of the CNV lesion will be calculated by adding up the size of the lesion in each subfield. The change in CNV size will be calculated by subtracting the size of the CNV lesion at baseline from the size of the CNV lesion at the end of the study.

### Changes in intra- or sub-retinal fluid measured as mean change in central retinal thickness or macula volume

The changes in intra- or sub-retinal fluid will be measured by comparing the central retinal thickness and macula volume at baseline and at the end of the study. The central retinal thickness and macula volume will be measured using optical coherence tomography (OCT). OCT is a non-invasive imaging technique that uses light waves to create high-resolution images of the retina. The central retinal thickness will be measured as the distance between the inner limiting membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium. The macula volume will be measured as the total volume of the macula. The changes in central retinal thickness and macula volume will be calculated by subtracting the central retinal thickness and macula volume at baseline from the central retinal thickness and macula volume at the end of the study.

Excellent! Here are the full outcome measures we have designed for the trial:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Revision rate of the femoral component: This measure evaluates the occurrence of aseptic loosening, not resultant from a tumor recurrence. It will be measured from baseline to a follow-up of 10 years.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Implant stability: Assessed through radiographic assessment of X-rays at follow-up, using immediate postoperative X-rays as a baseline. The time frame for this measure is also 10 years.
- Functionality evaluation: Measured using the Harris Hip Score up to the last available follow-up visit. The time frame for this measure is 10 years.
- Incidence of device-related adverse events or serious adverse events: Monitored throughout the study period to evaluate the safety profile of the Revision LR femoral stem. The time frame for this measure is 10 years.

# Introduction
The purpose of this article is to provide a framework for the design of outcome measures for clinical trials. The article is intended to be a practical guide for clinical trialists who are designing outcome measures for their clinical trials. The article is not intended to be a comprehensive review of the literature on outcome measures.

# Background
The design of outcome measures is an important part of the design of clinical trials. The choice of outcome measures can have a significant impact on the results of a clinical trial. The choice of outcome measures can also affect the interpretation of the results of a clinical trial.

NT-proBNP is a biomarker associated with heart failure and can serve as a valuable indicator of disease severity and response to treatment. The Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCQL) score is a validated tool for assessing health-related quality of life in heart failure patients. A 5-point change in KCQL score compared to baseline indicates a clinically significant improvement or decline in the patient's quality of life, which is an important aspect to consider in evaluating treatment success.
You can describe it as "5 point change in KCQL score compared to baseline."
An appropriate time frame for this measure would be "6 months."

The 6-minute walk test is a simple and practical measure of functional capacity and exercise tolerance in heart failure patients. A 25-meter change in the 6-minute walk test compared to baseline reflects improvement or decline in physical performance, which is relevant for assessing the overall impact of interventions on patient mobility and functional status.
You can describe it as "25 meter change in 6-minute walk test compared to baseline."
An appropriate time frame for this measure would be "6 months."

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Composite of cardiac mortality, heart transplant, or LVAD implantation: Occurrence of cardiac mortality and/or heart transplant and/or LVAD implantation, up to 36 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Change in FMR: A change of >5 units/percentage points compared to baseline, 6 months.
- Change in NT-proBNP: 30% change in NT-proBNP or decrease to level < 1000 compared to baseline, 6 months.
- Change in KCQL score: 5 point change in KCQL score compared to baseline, 6 months.
- Change in 6-minute walk test: 25 meter change in 6-minute walk test compared to baseline, 6 months.
- Recurrent heart failure hospitalization: Occurrence of heart failure-related hospitalization, up to 1 year.
- Arrhythmias: Occurrence of arrhythmia, up to 1 year.
- MI: Occurrence of myocardial infarction, up to 1 year.
- Stroke: Occurrence of stroke, up to 1 year.
- Heart transplant: Occurrence of heart transplant, up to 1 year.
- LVAD implantation: Occurrence of implant of left ventricular assisted device (LVAD), up to 1 year.
- Mortality: Occurrence of mortality, up to 1 year.

These outcome measures will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness and acceptability of virtual reality as an anxiety-reducing intervention.

# Introduction
The purpose of this guideline is to provide recommendations for the design of outcome measures for clinical trials in prostate cancer. The guideline is intended to assist researchers in designing outcome measures that are relevant, valid, reliable, and feasible for use in clinical trials. The guideline is not intended to be prescriptive, but rather to provide a framework for researchers to consider when designing outcome measures for clinical trials in prostate cancer.

# Background
Prostate cancer is a common cancer in men, with an estimated 1.4 million new cases diagnosed worldwide in 2020. The incidence of prostate cancer varies widely across the world, with the highest rates observed in North America, Europe, and Australia, and the lowest rates observed in Africa and Asia. Prostate cancer is the second most common cancer in men globally, after lung cancer. The incidence of prostate cancer is increasing in many parts of the world, particularly in low-and middle-income countries, due to changes in lifestyle and diet.
Prostate cancer is a heterogeneous disease, with a wide range of clinical presentations and outcomes. The most common form of prostate cancer is adenocarcinoma, which accounts for approximately 90% of cases. Other types of prostate cancer include neuroendocrine tumors, small cell carcinoma, and sarcoma. The prognosis for prostate cancer varies widely, depending on the stage of the disease at diagnosis. Early-stage prostate cancer is often treated with surgery or radiation therapy, while advanced-stage prostate cancer is often treated with chemotherapy or hormone therapy.
The treatment of prostate cancer has evolved over the past few decades, with the development of new therapies and the use of multimodal approaches. Surgery, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy are the most common treatments for prostate cancer. In recent years, there has been a shift towards the use of targeted therapies, such as immunotherapy and molecularly targeted therapies, which are designed to target specific molecules involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells.

This measure provides insights into the effectiveness of the intervention in maintaining participant engagement and adherence.

The Rate of Intervention Completion evaluates the feasibility of participants completing the intervention sessions. The study sets a goal of at least 70% of participants completing at least 70% of the intervention sessions from baseline to the 3-month follow-up. This measure helps gauge participant engagement and adherence to the intervention protocol.

The Improvement of Quality of Life measure focuses on assessing the intervention's impact on enhancing participants' quality of life. It will be evaluated using the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy-Bone Marrow Transplant scale (FACT-BMT). The FACT-BMT score range is 0-164, with higher scores indicating better quality of life. This measure will also be assessed from baseline to the 5-month follow-up.

The Improvement of Mood measure aims to evaluate the intervention's effects on anxiety and depression symptoms among participants. It will be assessed using the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS). The HADS anxiety and depression subscale score ranges from 0 to 21, with higher scores indicating worse anxiety and depression symptoms. This measure will also be evaluated from baseline to the 5-month follow-up.

# Introduction
Acanthosis nigricans (AN) is a skin condition characterized by hyperpigmentation and thickening of the skin. It is most commonly seen in obese individuals, but can also be seen in patients with insulin resistance, diabetes mellitus, and other endocrine disorders. AN is often asymptomatic, but can be associated with pruritus and discomfort. Treatment options for AN include lifestyle modifications, topical and oral medications, and surgical procedures.

# Historical Perspective
AN was first described in 1889 by the German dermatologist, Dr. Max Joseph von Pettenkofer. He described the condition as a "thickening of the skin in the neck and axillae." Since then, the condition has been studied and researched extensively.

# Classification
AN can be classified into three types:
- Type I: This type is seen in obese individuals and is characterized by thickening of the skin in the neck, axillae, and groin.
- Type II: This type is seen in patients with insulin resistance and is characterized by thickening of the skin in the neck, axillae, and groin.
- Type III: This type is seen in patients with endocrine disorders, such as diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism.

# Pathophysiology
The exact pathophysiology of AN is not fully understood, but it is thought to be related to insulin resistance. Insulin resistance is a condition in which the body does not respond properly to insulin, leading to an increase in blood sugar levels. This can cause an increase in the production of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), which is a hormone that promotes cell growth and proliferation. Increased levels of IGF-1 can lead to an increase in the thickness of the skin, which is characteristic of AN.

# Introduction

### Background

Opioid use disorder (OUD) is a chronic relapsing disorder that is characterized by compulsive opioid use despite negative consequences. OUD is a major public health problem in the United States, with an estimated 2.1 million people aged 12 or older having OUD in 2019. The prevalence of OUD is higher among people who are unemployed, have a history of incarceration, and have a history of substance use disorders.

### Importance

Opioid cessation is a critical component of OUD treatment. Opioid cessation is associated with improved quality of life, reduced pain, and reduced mortality. However, the effectiveness of opioid cessation is limited by high rates of relapse. The relapse rate is estimated to be 40% to 60% within 1 year of opioid cessation.

### Objective

To evaluate the effectiveness of opioid cessation in reducing opioid-induced esophageal dysfunction, chest pain, and dysphagia.

### Questions

### Primary

- What is the effectiveness of opioid cessation in reducing opioid-induced esophageal dysfunction, chest pain, and dysphagia?

### Secondary

- What is the effectiveness of opioid cessation in reducing opioid-induced esophageal dysfunction, chest pain, and dysphagia among people with OUD who are unemployed, have a history of incarceration, and have a history of substance use disorders?

# Introduction
The aim of this guideline is to provide guidance on the selection of outcome measures for clinical trials of interventions for people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

# Background
COPD is a common, preventable and treatable disease characterised by persistent airflow limitation that is usually progressive and associated with an enhanced chronic inflammatory response in the airways and the lung to noxious particles or gases. Exacerbations and comorbidities contribute to the overall severity in individual patients.
COPD is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In Australia, COPD is the third leading cause of death and the fourth leading cause of hospitalisation. The prevalence of COPD is increasing, and it is estimated that by 2020, COPD will be the fifth leading cause of disability worldwide.
The Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) defines COPD as a common preventable and treatable disease characterised by persistent airflow limitation that is usually progressive and associated with an enhanced chronic inflammatory response in the airways and the lung to noxious particles or gases. Exacerbations and comorbidities contribute to the overall severity in individual patients.
The GOLD guidelines recommend that the diagnosis of COPD should be based on the presence of persistent airflow limitation, which is defined as a post-bronchodilator forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1)/forced vital capacity (FVC) ratio of less than 0.70.
The GOLD guidelines also recommend that the severity of COPD should be classified using the GOLD ABCD classification system. This system uses the FEV1 to classify patients into four groups: A (mild), B (moderate), C (severe) and D (very severe).

In the United States, the incidence of cancer is increasing. In 2019, there were 1,762,450 new cancer cases and 606,880 cancer deaths. Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States. The incidence of cancer is expected to increase by 47% by 2040.

Cancer is a major public health problem. The incidence of cancer is increasing, and the number of cancer deaths is expected to increase by 47% by 2040. Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of two electrolyte maintenance solutions in pediatric cancer patients undergoing major surgeries.

### Research Question

What is the effectiveness of two electrolyte maintenance solutions in pediatric cancer patients undergoing major surgeries?

The null hypothesis is that there is no difference in the effectiveness of two electrolyte maintenance solutions in pediatric cancer patients undergoing major surgeries.

### Research Objective

The objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of two electrolyte maintenance solutions in pediatric cancer patients undergoing major surgeries.

### Research Design

This study is a randomized controlled trial.

This study will be conducted in a pediatric cancer center in the United States. The study population will include pediatric cancer patients undergoing major surgeries. The study will include 100 pediatric cancer patients undergoing major surgeries. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months.

### Study Population

The study population will include pediatric cancer patients undergoing major surgeries.

### Inclusion Criteria

The inclusion criteria for this study are as follows:

- Patients undergoing major surgeries
- Patients with cancer
- Patients aged 18 years or younger

### Exclusion Criteria

The exclusion criteria for this study are as follows:

- Patients with a history of major surger

# Introduction

### What is a clinical trial?
A clinical trial is a research study that involves human participants. It is designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a medical product, such as a drug, device, vaccine, or other intervention. Clinical trials are conducted in a controlled setting, such as a hospital or clinic, and involve a specific group of participants who are selected based on certain criteria. The participants are assigned to one of several groups, known as treatment arms, and are monitored closely throughout the trial to assess the safety and efficacy of the medical product.

### What is a clinical trial protocol?
A clinical trial protocol is a detailed plan that outlines the procedures and methods that will be used in a clinical trial. It is a document that is written by the research team and approved by an institutional review board (IRB) or ethics committee before the trial begins. The protocol provides a detailed description of the study design, including the eligibility criteria for participants, the interventions that will be tested, the outcome measures that will be used to assess the efficacy and safety of the interventions, and the procedures for data collection and analysis.

### What is a clinical trial outcome measure?
A clinical trial outcome measure is a tool used to assess the effectiveness of a medical product or intervention. It is a quantifiable indicator of the success or failure of a clinical trial. Outcome measures can be categorized into primary and secondary outcome measures. Primary outcome measures are the most important indicators of the success or failure of a clinical trial and are typically chosen based on the study's primary objective. Secondary outcome measures are less important indicators of the success or failure of a clinical trial and are typically chosen based on the study's secondary objectives.

# Introduction

This document provides guidance on the selection of outcome measures for clinical trials in the field of cancer. It is intended to assist researchers in the design of clinical trials and to help reviewers and editors assess the appropriateness of the outcome measures proposed.

# Background

The selection of outcome measures is an important part of the design of clinical trials. The choice of outcome measures should be based on the research question and the clinical context. The outcome measures should be relevant to the research question and should be able to detect a difference between the intervention and control groups. The outcome measures should also be feasible to measure in the clinical setting and should be acceptable to patients and clinicians.

# Methods

This guidance was developed by the Outcome Measures Working Group of the International Cancer Benchmarking Partnership (ICBP). The ICBP is a collaboration between the United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and the United States. The ICBP aims to compare the survival of patients with common cancers in different countries to identify areas for improvement in cancer care. The ICBP is funded by Cancer Research UK and the National Cancer Institute.

## Search strategy

A systematic review of the literature was conducted to identify outcome measures that have been used in clinical trials in the field of cancer. The search strategy was developed in collaboration with a librarian and was based on the PICO framework (population, intervention, comparison, and outcome). The search was conducted in the following databases:

# Introduction
The purpose of this protocol is to describe the design of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate the efficacy of a novel intervention for the treatment of chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps (CRSwNP). The intervention is a novel, minimally invasive, and cost-effective treatment that uses a combination of topical and systemic medications to target the underlying inflammatory pathways in CRSwNP. The trial will be conducted in a tertiary care hospital in India and will include a total of 100 participants. The trial will be conducted in accordance with the principles of Good Clinical Practice (GCP) and the Declaration of Helsinki.

## Background and rationale {6a}
Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is a common inflammatory condition of the nasal and paranasal sinuses that affects approximately 10% of the global population   Chronic rhinosinusitis: epidemiology and medical management, Hamilos  . CRS is characterized by persistent inflammation of the nasal and paranasal sinus mucosa, which can lead to a variety of symptoms, including nasal congestion, nasal discharge, facial pain or pressure, and reduced sense of smell   Chronic rhinosinusitis: epidemiology and medical management, Hamilos  . CRS can be classified into two subtypes: CRS with nasal polyps (CRSwNP) and CRS without nasal polyps (CRSsNP). CRSwNP is a more severe form of CRS that is characterized by the presence of nasal polyps, which are non-cancerous growths that can cause significant nasal obstruction and impairment of olfactory function   Chronic rhinosinusitis: epidemiology and medical management, Hamilos  .
The pathophysiology of CRSwNP is complex and involves a combination of genetic, environmental, and immunological factors   Chronic rhinosinusitis: epidemiology and medical management, Hamilos  . Excellent! Now let's move on to the secondary outcome measures. We have several options to consider based on the study objectives and the nature of the treatment. We can start with the overall response rate (ORR) measured by mRECIST criteria. What are your thoughts on including this measure?

I completely agree. The overall response rate (ORR) is a standard measure of treatment response in oncology trials. By using the mRECIST criteria, which are specifically designed for assessing treatment response in hepatocellular carcinoma, we can accurately evaluate the treatment's impact on tumor regression. We can measure ORR from the date of first treatment to radiographically documented progression according to mRECIST, with an assessment period of up to 3 years. How does that sound?

Great! Now let's continue with the other secondary outcome measures. We have options such as time to progression (TTP), time to intrahepatic tumor progression (TTITP), progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), incidence of study-related adverse events, pathological response, disease control rate (DCR), duration of response, and quality of life (QoL) after treatment. Which measures would you like to include?

That's an excellent choice! Including all of those measures will give us a comprehensive understanding of the treatment's effectiveness and impact on different aspects of patient outcomes. We can measure time to progression (TTP), time to intrahepatic tumor progression (TTITP), progression-free survival (PFS), and overall survival (OS) from the date of first treatment to radiographically documented progression or death from any cause. Incidence of study-related adverse events can be measured from the date of first treatment to 90 days after the last treatment. Pathological response can be assessed from the date of first treatment to radiographically documented progression or death from any cause, with an assessment period of up to 5 years. Disease control rate (DCR) can be measured from the date of first treatment to radiographically documented response according to mRECIST, assessed up to 3 years. Duration of response can be defined as the time from first documented evidence of complete response (CR) or partial response (PR) until the first documented sign of disease progression (PD) or death from any cause. Lastly, quality of life (QoL) after treatment can be assessed from the date of first follow-up to radiographically documented progression or death from any cause, up to 3 years. How does this sound?

Monitoring the incidence of adverse events/reactions, both solicited and unsolicited, is crucial to ensure participant safety. Perfect! We now have a comprehensive set of primary and secondary outcome measures for your clinical trial on the inactivated rotavirus vaccine. Here they are:

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Immunogenicity index-geometric mean titer (GMT) of neutralizing antibody: Measure the GMT of neutralizing antibodies 28 days after the final dose.
2. Immunogenicity index-geometric mean increase (GMI) of neutralizing antibody: Assess the increase in neutralizing antibodies from baseline to 28 days after the final dose.
3. Immunogenicity index-seroconversion rates of neutralizing antibody: Determine the proportion of participants who develop a seropositive response between baseline and 28 days after the final dose.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Safety index-incidence of adverse reactions/events: Monitor the incidence of adverse reactions/events within 30 minutes after each dose.
2. Safety index-incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events: Assess the incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events within 7 days after each dose.
3. Safety index-incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events: Evaluate the incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events within 28/30 days after each dose.
4. Safety index-incidence of serious adverse events: Track the occurrence of serious adverse reactions/events from the beginning of vaccination up to 6 months after the final dose.

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Kinesiophobia: The Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia - Swedish version for the heart will be used to assess the subjective rating of kinesiophobia. This measure will be taken at baseline, after the 8-week program, and 3 months after program completion.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- ActiGraph (accelerometer): An accelerometer will objectively assess participants' physical activity levels during the day. This measure will be taken at the same time points as the primary outcome measure.
- Physical exercise behavior: The Stages of Change model will be used to assess participants' level of exercise behavior change. This measure will be taken at the same time points as the primary outcome measure.
- Self-efficacy: Participants' general self-efficacy will be assessed using a four-point Likert scale. This measure will be taken at the same time points as the primary outcome measure.
- Heart focused anxiety: The Cardiac Anxiety scale will be used to assess participants' anxiety related to their heart condition. This measure will be taken at the same time points as the primary outcome measure.
- Self-rated health: Participants' overall perception of their health status will be assessed using the EuroQol-visual analogue scales. This measure will be taken at the same time points as the primary outcome measure.
- Patients' experiences of the digital program: Individual semi-structured interviews will be conducted to gather qualitative data on participants' experiences. These interviews will take place after the 8-week program.

# Introduction
Heart failure (HF) is a complex clinical syndrome characterized by the inability of the heart to pump blood at a rate and volume sufficient to meet the metabolic demands of the body. It is a major public health problem, with an estimated prevalence of 1-2% in the general population and up to 10% in people over 70 years of age. HF is a leading cause of hospitalization and mortality worldwide, with an estimated annual incidence of 1-2 million cases and a mortality rate of 50% at 5 years.

# Introduction

### Background

Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNpc) and the presence of Lewy bodies in the surviving neurons. The clinical manifestations of PD include motor symptoms such as bradykinesia, rigidity, tremor, and postural instability, as well as non-motor symptoms such as depression, anxiety, and cognitive impairment. The diagnosis of PD is based on the presence of motor symptoms and the exclusion of other conditions that can cause similar symptoms.

### Rationale

The diagnosis of PD is based on the presence of motor symptoms and the exclusion of other conditions that can cause similar symptoms. However, the diagnosis of PD can be challenging, especially in the early stages of the disease, when the symptoms are mild or non-specific. In these cases, it is important to use imaging techniques to confirm the diagnosis and to monitor the progression of the disease.

### Objectives

The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the prognostic value of the PET examination in the early diagnosis of PD. The secondary objective is to compare the diagnostic accuracy of different analysis methods in the differential diagnosis between PD and parkinsonism.

### Research Questions

- What is the prognostic value of the PET examination in the early diagnosis of PD?
- What is the diagnostic accuracy of different analysis methods in the differential diagnosis between PD and parkinsonism?

### Study Design

This is a prospective observational study that will include patients with suspected PD who will undergo a PET examination with the radiotracer 11C-Fe_CIT. The results of the PET examination will be analyzed with both the ROI and SPM voxel-based methods. The prognostic value of the PET examination in the early diagnosis of PD will be evaluated by comparing the results of the PET examination with the clinical diagnosis of PD at the end of the study. Excellent choice! Lastly, we could consider including the proportion of participants with a ≥4-point reduction in the weekly average of daily Peak Pruritus-Numerical Rating Scale (PP-NRS) from baseline in participants with a baseline weekly average of daily PP-NRS ≥4. Wonderful! We have successfully designed the outcome measures for your clinical trial. Here are the full outcome measures:

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Proportion of participants with Validated Investigator Global Assessment scale for Atopic Dermatitis (vIGA-AD) of 0 (clear) or 1 (almost clear) and a reduction from baseline of ≥2 points at Week 36.
2. Proportion of participants reaching 75% reduction from baseline in Eczema Area and Severity Index (EASI) score (EASI75) at Week 36.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Proportion of participants reaching EASI-75 at Week 24.
2. Proportion of participants with vIGA-AD 0 (clear) or 1 (almost clear) with the presence of only barely perceptible erythema.
3. Proportion of participants with a ≥4-point reduction in the weekly average of daily Peak Pruritus-Numerical Rating Scale (PP-NRS) from baseline in participants with a baseline weekly average of daily PP-NRS ≥4.

These measures will provide a comprehensive assessment of the treatment's efficacy and its impact on various aspects of AD. Is there anything else I can assist you with?

# Introduction
Advance care planning (ACP) is a process that allows individuals to communicate their preferences for future medical care and to designate a surrogate decision-maker. ACP is an important part of end-of-life care and can help ensure that individuals receive the care they want if they become unable to make decisions for themselves. ACP is also important for individuals who are at risk of experiencing a serious illness or injury. By discussing their preferences for future medical care, individuals can ensure that they receive the best possible care if they become unable to make decisions for themselves.

# Introduction
The purpose of this tutorial is to demonstrate how to design outcome measures for a clinical trial. The outcome measures are the measures that are used to assess the effectiveness of the intervention. The outcome measures should be chosen carefully to ensure that they are relevant to the study and that they can be measured accurately.

## Choosing outcome measures
When choosing outcome measures, it is important to consider the following:
- The purpose of the study: What are you trying to achieve with the study?
- The type of study: Is it a randomized controlled trial (RCT), a cohort study, or a case-control study?
- The population: Who are you studying?
- The intervention: What is the intervention that you are testing?
- The setting: Where is the study taking place?
- The time frame: How long will the study last?
- The resources: What resources do you have available to conduct the study?
- The outcome measures: What outcomes will you be measuring?

## Randomized controlled trial
A randomized controlled trial (RCT) is a type of study in which participants are randomly assigned to receive either the intervention or the control. The purpose of an RCT is to compare the effectiveness of the intervention to the control.

## Cohort study
A cohort study is a type of study in which a group of people who share a common characteristic are followed over time to see if they develop a certain outcome. The purpose of a cohort study is to identify risk factors for the outcome.

## Case-control study
A case-control study is a type of study in which a group of people who have a certain outcome (cases) are compared to a group of people who do not have the outcome (controls). The purpose of a case-control study is to identify risk factors for the outcome.

## Population
The population is the group of people that you are studying. It is important to choose a population that is relevant to the study and that can be easily accessed.

## Intervention
The intervention is the treatment or exposure that you are testing. It is important to choose an intervention that is relevant to the study and that can be delivered in a controlled manner.

## Setting
The setting is the place where the study will take place. It is important to choose a setting that is appropriate for the study and that

# Introduction
The aim of this article is to provide an overview of the process of developing and selecting outcome measures for a clinical trial. The article is intended for researchers who are planning to conduct a clinical trial and are looking for guidance on how to select outcome measures. The article will cover the following topics:

# Background

## What is a clinical trial?
A clinical trial is a research study that evaluates the safety and effectiveness of a medical product, such as a drug, device, or treatment. The goal of a clinical trial is to generate evidence that can be used to make informed decisions about the use of the medical product in clinical practice.

## What is an outcome measure?
An outcome measure is a tool used to assess the effectiveness of a medical product or treatment. It is typically used to measure the change in a patient's health status or quality of life before and after receiving the treatment.

## Why are outcome measures important?
Outcome measures are important because they provide a way to evaluate the effectiveness of a medical product or treatment. By measuring the change in a patient's health status or quality of life before and after receiving the treatment, researchers can determine whether the treatment is effective and safe.

## What are the different types of outcome measures?
There are several different types of outcome measures, including:
- Primary outcome measures: These are the most important measures and are used to determine the effectiveness of the treatment.
- Secondary outcome measures: These are less important measures and are used to provide additional information about the treatment.
- Exploratory outcome measures: These are used to generate new hypotheses about the treatment.

## How are outcome measures selected?
The selection of outcome measures is a critical step in the planning of a clinical trial. It is important to choose outcome measures that are relevant to the research question and that can be measured accurately and reliably. The following are some factors to consider when selecting outcome measures:
- The research question: The outcome measures should be relevant to the research question and should be able to answer the question.
- The population: The outcome measures should be appropriate for the population being studied.
- The intervention: The outcome measures should be able to measure the effect of the intervention.
- The setting: The outcome measures should be able to be measured in the setting where the intervention will be used.

# Introduction
This page provides an overview of the outcome measures for the clinical trial.

## Primary Outcome Measure
The primary outcome measure is the incidence of IELN invasion by ovarian cancer.

## Secondary Outcome Measures
The secondary outcome measures are:
- The proportion of invaded IELN
- The proportion of invaded IELN in correlation with the patient's PCI and the specific peritoneal zones affected by the disease
- The accuracy of preoperative imaging in detecting IELN invasion

## Outcome Measure: Incidence of IELN Invasion by Ovarian Cancer

### Measure Description
The incidence of IELN invasion by ovarian cancer is the proportion of patients with ovarian cancer who have IELN invasion.

### Measure Calculation
The incidence of IELN invasion by ovarian cancer is calculated as the number of patients with ovarian cancer who have IELN invasion divided by the total number of patients with ovarian cancer.

### Measure Validity
The validity of the incidence of IELN invasion by ovarian cancer is determined by the accuracy of the histopathological analysis of the IELN.

### Measure Reliability

### SGLT2 Inhibitors

- SGLT2 inhibitors are a class of medications that are used to treat type 2 diabetes.
- They work by blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, which leads to increased urinary excretion of glucose and a reduction in blood glucose levels.
- SGLT2 inhibitors are also known to have cardiovascular benefits, including a reduction in blood pressure and a decrease in body weight.
- In addition, SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to improve heart failure outcomes in patients with type 2 diabetes.

### sGC Stimulators

- sGC stimulators are a class of medications that are used to treat heart failure.
- They work by stimulating the enzyme soluble guanylate cyclase (sGC), which is involved in the production of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP).
- cGMP is a second messenger that regulates a variety of cellular processes, including vascular tone and cellular metabolism.
- By stimulating sGC, sGC stimulators increase the production of cGMP, which leads to improved heart function and reduced symptoms of heart failure.

### ARNI

- ARNI is a medication that is used to treat heart failure.
- It is a combination of two drugs, angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) and neprilysin inhibitor (NEPi).
- ARB works by blocking the angiotensin II receptor, which is involved in the regulation of blood pressure and fluid balance.
- NEPi works by inhibiting the enzyme neprilysin, which is involved in the degradation of natriuretic peptides.
- By blocking the angiotensin II receptor and inhibiting neprilysin, ARNI helps to improve heart function and reduce symptoms of heart failure.

# Background

## Problem
Heart failure is a chronic condition that affects millions of people worldwide. It is characterized by the inability of the heart to pump blood effectively, leading to fluid buildup in the body. Heart failure can be caused by a variety of factors, including coronary artery disease, hypertension, and valvular heart disease.
The management of heart failure involves a combination of lifestyle changes, medications, and, in some cases, surgery. One of the most important aspects of heart failure management is the use of diuretics, which help to reduce fluid buildup in the body. However, diuretics can also cause electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to serious complications.
One of the most common electrolyte imbalances associated with heart failure is hypokalemia, which is characterized by low potassium levels in the blood. Hypokalemia can cause a variety of symptoms, including muscle weakness, fatigue, and cramps. In severe cases, hypokalemia can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and even death.

The CONSORT-SPI 2018 Extension for Social Media Interventions (CONSORT-SPI) provides guidance on reporting randomized trials of social media interventions. The CONSORT-SPI 2018 Extension is an extension of the CONSORT 2010 Statement (CONSORT 2010) and the CONSORT-EHEALTH checklist (CONSORT-EHEALTH V1.6.1).
The CONSORT-SPI 2018 Extension is intended to help authors report randomized trials of social media interventions. Perfect! Another significant secondary outcome measure is endoleak. This measure evaluates the rate of persistence of blood flow outside the lumen of the endoluminal graft. Primary endoleaks occur within 30 days post-procedure, and secondary (or late) endoleaks are detected after 30 days and subsequent to previous negative images. We can measure this outcome at the end of surgery/procedure, 1 month, 6 months, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 years. What are your thoughts on this?

Great! We're almost done. Another essential secondary outcome measure is reintervention-free rate. This measure assesses the absence of open surgical and/or endovascular reinterventions. We can measure this outcome at the end of surgery/procedure, 1 month, 6 months, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 years. What do you think?

Wonderful! Lastly, let's include adverse events as a secondary outcome measure. This measure captures all-cause mortality, retrograde type A dissection, aortic rupture, permanent paraplegia and paraparesis, stent-induced new entry tear, conversion to open repair, disabling stroke, and non-preexisting renal failure. We can measure this outcome at the end of surgery/procedure, 1 month, 6 months, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 years. What are your thoughts on this?

Perfect! Here are the complete outcome measures for your clinical trial:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Early occurrence of adverse events (Safety Outcome): Assess the rate of major adverse events, including all-cause mortality, acute myocardial infarction, stroke, permanent paraplegia, and renal failure, at 1 month post the index procedure.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Device Success: Evaluate the rate of successful introduction, navigation, and deployment of the device at the intended site intraoperatively.
- Absence of endoprosthesis fracture: Monitor the rate of absence of endoprosthesis fracture at 1 month and 1 year post-procedure.
- Endoleak: Assess the rate of persistence of blood flow outside the lumen of the endoluminal graft at the end of surgery/procedure, 1 month, 6 months, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 years.
- Reintervention-free: Measure the rate of absence of open surgical and endovascular reinterventions at the end of surgery/procedure, 1 month, 6 months, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 years.
- Adverse Events: Capture all-cause mortality, retrograde type A dissection, aortic rupture, permanent paraplegia and paraparesis, stent-induced new entry tear, conversion to open repair, disabling stroke, and non-preexisting renal failure at the end of surgery/procedure, 1 month, 6 months, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 years.

# Introduction
The purpose of this article is to provide guidance on how to design and implement outcome measures for clinical trials. The article is intended for researchers who are designing clinical trials and want to ensure that their outcome measures are valid, reliable, and feasible. The article will cover the following topics:
- The importance of outcome measures in clinical trials
- The different types of outcome measures
- How to choose the right outcome measures for your clinical trial
- How to design and implement outcome measures for clinical trials
- How to evaluate the effectiveness of outcome measures

## The importance of outcome measures in clinical trials
Clinical trials are essential for evaluating the safety and efficacy of new treatments and interventions. They are also used to compare different treatments and interventions to determine which is most effective. Without outcome measures, it would be impossible to determine whether a new treatment or intervention is safe and effective.

## The different types of outcome measures
There are many different types of outcome measures that can be used in clinical trials. The most common types of outcome measures are:
- Primary outcome measures: These are the most important outcome measures in a clinical trial. They are used to determine whether a new treatment or intervention is safe and effective.
- Secondary outcome measures: These are less important outcome measures in a clinical trial. They are used to provide additional information about the safety and efficacy of a new treatment or intervention.
- Exploratory outcome measures: These are used to explore new treatments or interventions that may be effective. They are not as important as primary or secondary outcome measures.

## How to choose the right outcome measures for your clinical trial
When choosing outcome measures for your clinical trial, it is important to consider the following factors:
- The purpose of the clinical trial
- The type of treatment or intervention being evaluated
- The population being studied
- The resources available to you
- The time frame of the clinical trial
- The feasibility of collecting the data
- The validity and reliability of the outcome measures

## How to design and implement outcome measures for clinical trials
When designing outcome measures for clinical trials, it is important to consider the following factors:
- The purpose of the clinical trial
- The type of treatment or intervention

Great! We have now discussed the primary and secondary outcome measures for your clinical trial. Here they are:

Primary Outcome Measure:
1. Albumin degradation rate by stable isotope:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure aims to determine the catabolic rate of albumin by measuring the disappearance rate of 2H5-phenylalanine labeled albumin over time in blood samples. It will be compared between patients with liver disease and healthy volunteers.
   - Time Frame: The albumin degradation rate will be measured over a period of 12 weeks.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Albumin synthesis rate:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure involves comparing the oral flooding dose with historical controls where the isotope was given intravenously to measure albumin synthesis rates in volunteers and patients with liver disease.
   - Time Frame: The albumin synthesis rate will be assessed within 120 minutes after the administration of the stable isotope labeled amino acid.

2. Albumin degradation by modeling different fractions of oxidized albumin over time:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure aims to investigate the relationship between oxidation and degradation of albumin by modeling different fractions of oxidized albumin over a period of 12 weeks.
   - Time Frame: The modeling of albumin degradation based on oxidized fractions will be conducted over a 12-week period.

3. Correlation between oxidation and degradation rate of albumin:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure seeks to determine if there is a correlation between oxidation fraction and albumin degradation rate, particularly in patients with liver disease over 12 weeks.
   - Time Frame: The correlation between oxidation and degradation rate of albumin will be assessed over a 12-week period.

## Summary
This article provides a step-by-step guide to designing outcome measures for a clinical trial. It is based on the experience of the authors in designing outcome measures for a clinical trial. The article provides a framework for designing outcome measures and discusses the importance of selecting appropriate outcome measures for a clinical trial. The article also provides a list of potential outcome measures that can be used in clinical trials.

## Outcome measures in clinical trials
Outcome measures are an essential part of clinical trials. They are used to assess the effectiveness of a treatment or intervention. There are many different types of outcome measures, and the choice of outcome measure depends on the type of clinical trial being conducted.

## Primary outcome measures
Primary outcome measures are the most important outcomes in a clinical trial. They are used to assess the effectiveness of a treatment or intervention. Primary outcome measures are usually measured at the end of the trial.

## Secondary outcome measures
Secondary outcome measures are used to assess the effectiveness of a treatment or intervention. Secondary outcome measures are usually measured at the end of the trial.

## Tertiary outcome measures
Tertiary outcome measures are used to assess the safety of a treatment or intervention. Tertiary outcome measures are usually measured throughout the trial.

## Quaternary outcome measures
Quaternary outcome measures are used to assess the cost-effectiveness of a treatment or intervention. Quaternary outcome measures are usually measured throughout the trial.

## Quinary outcome measures
Quinary outcome measures are used to assess the quality of life of patients. Quinary outcome measures are usually measured throughout the trial.

Additionally, we can measure the participant's vision-related quality of life using the NEI VFQ-25 questionnaire at baseline, Week 36, and Week 64. This will provide insights into the overall impact of the treatment on the participants' daily lives. What do you think of these suggestions?

I'm glad you find them helpful! Lastly, we should also consider safety measures. We can track the number of participants who experience treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) and serious adverse events (SAEs) through Weeks 36 and 64. This will help us assess the safety profile of the higher dose of Aflibercept. Additionally, we can monitor the systemic exposure to Aflibercept by assessing plasma concentrations of free, adjusted bound, and total Aflibercept from baseline through Weeks 36 and 64. This will provide insights into the drug's pharmacokinetics. What are your thoughts on these safety measures?

I completely agree with you. It's essential to prioritize participant safety in any clinical trial. Based on our discussion, here are the full outcome measures for your study:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Change from baseline in BCVA measured by the ETDRS letter score at Week 36

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Number of active injections from baseline to Week 64
- Number of active injections from baseline to Week 36
- Change from baseline in BCVA measured by the ETDRS letter score at Week 44
- Change from baseline in BCVA measured by the ETDRS letter score at Week 64
- Number of participants gaining at least 15 letters in BCVA from baseline at Weeks 36 and 64
- Number of participants achieving an ETDRS letter score of at least 69 at Weeks 36 and 64
- Participant having no intraretinal fluid (IRF) and no subretinal fluid (SRF) in the center subfield at Weeks 36 and 64
- Change from baseline in central subfield thickness (CST) at Weeks 36 and 64
- Change from baseline in NEI VFQ-25 total score at Weeks 36 and 64
- Number of participants with treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) and serious adverse events (SAEs) through Weeks 36 and 64
- Participants dosed only Q8W through Week 36 in the 8 mg Q8W group
- Participants having last treatment intervals ≥12 or of 16 weeks at Week 64
- Participants having next intended interval ≥12 or of 16 weeks at Week 64
- Systemic exposure to Aflibercept as assessed by plasma concentrations of free, adjusted bound, and total Aflibercept from baseline through Weeks 36 and 64

Absolutely. Let's go through the secondary outcome measures one by one. The first measure is the Brief Pain Inventory - Numeric Rating Scale. This measure assesses pain intensity by asking about worst and least pain intensity in the past 24 hours, pain on average, and pain right now. It uses an 11-point scale, with zero representing 'no pain' and 10 representing the 'worst imaginable pain'. This measure has been shown to have excellent reliability and validity in people with knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is the Modified Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI). This measure assesses the presence of comorbidities in participants, including knee osteoarthritis. The CCI has been widely used in various patient populations, including knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is endogenous pain modulation, which assesses the efficiency of pain modulation mechanisms in individuals with knee osteoarthritis. We can use the conditioned pain modulation (CPM) testing method to evaluate this measure. By assessing the ascending measure of pressure pain threshold (PPT) at the anterior shin and the conditioning stimulus in the form of forearm ischemia, we can calculate the percent efficiency of CPM (%CPM) as PPT2/PPT1 multiplied by 100. This measure can provide insights into the neurobiological effects of the intervention. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks.

The other secondary outcome measures include pain interference, pain catastrophizing, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), multi-joint pain assessed through a body diagram, knee awareness, functional leg strength, medication use, adverse events, patient global impression of change, blinding effectiveness, usefulness of the program for managing knee OA, frequency of the program, duration of the program, acceptability of the delivery of the brain stimulation, acceptability of the delivery of the yoga session of the program, likelihood of recommending the program to others with knee OA, burdensomeness of completing questionnaires and physical assessments, adherence rate, and rate of completion of home sessions. Each of these measures serves a specific purpose and provides valuable information on various aspects of the intervention and study outcomes.

Certainly! The "Timed up & go Test" measures the total time taken for a participant to arise from a chair, walk 3 meters, turn around, return to the chair, and sit down. It is recorded to the nearest 10th of a second. This test will be conducted on the first day after surgery and the third or fourth day after surgery to assess immediate postoperative functional ability.

The "Numeric Pain Rating Scale" is an 11-point scale that quantifies pain intensity, ranging from 0 (no pain) to 10 (the most intense pain imaginable). Participants will be asked to rate their pain levels up to four days after surgery, allowing us to evaluate the effectiveness of the nerve block in managing postoperative pain.

The "Quadriceps Muscle Strength" will be measured using a dynamometer in N⋅m units. This outcome measure assesses the participants' muscle strength and will be evaluated a day before surgery, the first day after surgery, and the third or fourth day after surgery to monitor changes and improvements in muscle function.

I'm glad you find them appropriate. Now, let's discuss the secondary outcome measures. These measures provide additional insights into various aspects of the participants' recovery and overall outcomes.

For the secondary outcome measures, I suggest considering the "Elderly Mobility Scale", the "5 Times Sit to Stand Test", the "Hospitalization Duration", the "Surgery Duration", the "Consumption of Analgesics", the "Occurrence of Falls", and the "Oxford Knee Score Questionnaire". These measures will help assess mobility, lower limb strength, hospitalization duration, surgical complexity, pain management, falls, and knee function, respectively.

Certainly! The "Elderly Mobility Scale" is a validated assessment tool that measures the mobility and independence of elderly participants. It uses an ordinal scale of 0-20, with scores indicating different levels of mobility and independence. This measure will be assessed on the first day after surgery and the third or fourth day after surgery.

The "5 Times Sit to Stand Test" measures the time taken for a patient to transfer from a seated to a standing position and back to sitting five times. This test evaluates lower limb strength and functional mobility and will be assessed on the first day after surgery and the third or fourth day after surgery.

"Hospitalization Duration" measures the number of days the participants spend hospitalized after surgery. It provides insights into the recovery progress and potential complications. This measure will be assessed at discharge, up to day 10.

"Surgery Duration" measures the duration of the surgical procedure and provides insights into the procedural aspects and their potential influence on recovery and outcomes. This measure will be recorded during the surgery.

"Consumption of Analgesics" measures the amount of analgesics consumed by the participants post-surgery. It helps in assessing the effectiveness of pain management strategies, including the nerve block. This measure will be assessed at discharge, up to day 10.

"Occurrence of Falls" assesses the occurrence of falls during hospitalization, which can have significant implications for patient safety and recovery. This measure will be assessed at discharge, up to day 10.

The "Oxford Knee Score Questionnaire" is a patient-reported outcome measure that assesses knee function and severity of problems related to knee arthritis. It provides a single summed score reflecting the severity of knee problems. This measure will be assessed a day before surgery.

You're welcome! I'm glad the outcome measures are comprehensive and suitable for your study. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask. Good luck with your clinical trial!

groundtruth: The assessment of the change in CAP score will be done after 3 months of taking SIM01. This time frame allows for a sufficient duration to observe potential changes in liver fat accumulation. It aligns with the study's goal of assessing the short-term effects of SIM01 on liver function in NAFLD patients.

Changes in liver enzymes, specifically ALT and AST levels, were chosen as secondary outcome measures because they are essential in evaluating liver function and detecting liver damage. These enzymes can indicate improvements or worsening of liver health. By assessing the change in ALT and AST levels over the study period, researchers can determine the impact of SIM01 on liver function in NAFLD patients.

Changes in fasting lipid and HbA1c levels were chosen as secondary outcome measures because they are important markers of metabolic health and are commonly dysregulated in individuals with NAFLD. Monitoring changes in these parameters can provide valuable information on the effects of SIM01 on metabolic function and overall health. By assessing the changes in lipid profiles and HbA1c levels, researchers can evaluate the potential benefits of SIM01 in improving metabolic parameters in NAFLD patients.

The time frame for assessing changes in liver enzymes, fasting lipid and HbA1c levels, BMI, body waist circumference, and IL-6 levels is also 3 months. This duration allows for comprehensive monitoring of these measures over an adequate period to capture potential changes in liver function, metabolic health, body weight management, abdominal obesity, and immune response in response to SIM01.

Certainly! Here are the full outcome measures for this study:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Change in Controlled Attenuation Parameter (CAP) score by fibroscan after taking SIM01 for 3 months: The change of CAP score measured by fibroscan. The CAP score is a measurement of fat accumulation in the liver to further determine the steatosis grade. The higher the score, the more severe the steatosis is. This measure assesses the impact of SIM01 on liver fat accumulation.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Change in liver enzymes (ALT and AST) across the study period: The change in the level of liver enzymes.
- Change in fasting lipid and HbA1c levels across the study period: The change in the level of lipid profiles.
- Change of body mass index (BMI) across the study period: The change in body weight and body height.
- Change of body waist circumference across the study period: The change in waist circumference.
- Change in interleukin-6 (IL-6) across the study period: The change in one of the immunity markers.

These outcome measures will help researchers evaluate the effectiveness of SIM01 in improving liver function, metabolic health, body weight management, abdominal obesity, and immune response in female subjects with NAFLD.

### 1. Decision-to-departure time

This is the time from the decision for MT to departure of the patient from the primary stroke center to the primary thrombectomy center.

### 2. Decision-to-arrival time

This is the time from the decision for MT to arrival of the patient at the primary thrombectomy center.

### 3. Arrival-to-groin time

This is the time from arrival of the patient at the primary thrombectomy center to groin puncture (start of mechanical thrombectomy procedure).

### 4. Rate of refusal of transfer requests due to lack of capacity

This is the rate of patients that had to be transferred to a secondary thrombectomy center instead of the primary thrombectomy center due to lack of capacity in the referral clinic.

### 5. Decision-to-transfer request time

This is the time from decision for MT to request of emergency medical service for interhospital transfer.

### 6. Periprocedural complications

This is the rate of periprocedural complications during MT.

### 7. Successful outcome of MT (mTICI > 2b)

This is the rate of successfully performed MT (mTICI > 2b) of all patients with attempted MT.

### 8. Groin-to-recanalization time

This is the time from groin puncture to successful recanalization.

### 9. Adverse events within 7 days

This is the rate of adverse events within the first 7 days after transfer to the referral center.

Absolutely! In addition to the CR/CRh rate, there are several other important secondary outcome measures to consider. These include:

1. Incidence and severity of adverse events (safety and tolerability): We can monitor the number and grade of adverse events assessed by CTCAE v5.0 over the course of approximately 36 months. This will help us assess the safety and tolerability of the combination therapy.

2. Duration of response: Measuring the time from randomization to disease progression or death in patients who achieve CR/CRh will provide insights into the durability of treatment response.

3. Post baseline transfusion independence rate: Assessing the rate of conversion from baseline transfusion dependence to transfusion independence will help us understand the impact of treatment on patients' quality of life.

4. Progression-free survival: Evaluating the time from randomization until the first evidence of disease progression or death will provide valuable information on the treatment's ability to control disease progression and prolong survival.

5. Relapse-free survival: Monitoring the number of participants alive without relapse will help us assess the long-term effectiveness of the combination therapy in preventing disease relapse.

6. Overall survival: Measuring the time from randomization to death will provide essential data on the treatment's impact on overall survival outcomes.

7. Percentage of patients bridged to hematopoietic stem cell transplantation: Assessing the number of hematopoietic stem cell transplantations following response will provide insights into the potential of the combination therapy to facilitate curative treatment options.

8. Impact of treatment on HM-PRO (hematologic malignancy-specific patient-reported outcome measure): Evaluating the treatment's impact on patients' health-related quality of life and disease-related signs and symptoms using the HM-PRO scales will provide a holistic understanding of the treatment's effects.

Certainly! Here are the outcome measures we have discussed:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Recording of significant stimulation-induced adverse events (AE): We aim to have an overall AE rate of less than 10% per cohort.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Recording of total ventilation time: This measure will help assess the impact of stimulation on reducing intubation time.
- Measurement of diaphragm thickness: We will use ultrasound to monitor diaphragm muscle thickness and evaluate muscle preservation.
- Assessment of diaphragm and respiratory muscle EMG amplitudes: This measure will provide insights into muscle activity and function.
- Measurement of respiratory pressure: Monitoring peak inspiratory and expiratory pressure will help evaluate respiratory strength and airway patency.
- Assessment of respiratory tidal volume: This measure will help assess lung capacity and efficiency.
- Measurement of ventilator weaning time: We will record the time taken to liberate patients from mechanical ventilation.

Full Outcome Measures:
Primary Outcome Measure:
- Preferred operation for acute colonic diverticular disease: Laparoscopic peritoneal lavage or sigmoid resection. Time frame: Up to 78 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Crossover surgery: Crossover from laparoscopy to resection surgery. Time frame: 1 day.
- Reoperation: Disease-associated reoperations involving the bowel or abdominal wall. Time frame: From date of inclusion until the date of the end of study or date of death from any cause, whichever came first, assessed up to 78 months.
- Overall survival: From date of inclusion until the date of the end of study or date of death from any cause, whichever came first, assessed up to 78 months.
- Postoperative length of hospital stay: From date of inclusion until the date of discharge, assessed up to 78 months.
- Colorectal cancer diagnosis: From date of inclusion until the date of the end of study or date of death from any cause, whichever came first, assessed up to 78 months.
- Thirty-day postoperative mortality: Up to 30 days.

Thank you for designing the outcome measures for your clinical trial. Here is the summary of the outcome measures you have designed:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Pressure muscle index (PMI) as a bedside estimation of inspiratory effort at different expiratory cycling levels during different levels of pressure support ventilation. Measure Description: To verify whether PMI correlates differently with esophageal pressure swing by changing expiratory cycling over different levels of pressure support ventilation. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Correlation between PMI and other measures of inspiratory effort (Pocc) and inspiratory drive (P0.1). Measure Description: To evaluate the correlation between different measures of inspiratory effort and inspiratory drive with PMI obtained at various degrees of expiratory cycling and different levels of pressure support. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.
- Airway resistances during assisted mechanical ventilation. Measure Description: To evaluate if airway resistance, evaluated by esophageal pressure, correlates with the estimation of airway resistance on the pressure-time waveform. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.
- Tidal volume variability. Measure Description: To evaluate tidal variability across different levels of pressure support ventilation and different levels of expiratory cycling and investigate how tidal variability correlates with inspiratory effort using deltaPes, PMI, and Pocc. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.

The authors report a case of a 40-year-old man with a history of aortic valve replacement and aortic root replacement with a Dacron graft 10 years ago. He was admitted to our hospital because of a sudden onset of severe chest pain. Echocardiography showed a large pericardial effusion and aortic root abscess. Emergency operation was performed. The abscess was found to be located in the aortic root and the aortic valve was destroyed. The abscess was excised and the aortic root was replaced with a homograft. The patient recovered uneventfully. .
